sv:property.sv:value: Imports setup automatically on model import.
import mortgages.Applicant import mortgages.Bankruptcy import mortgages.IncomeSource import mortgages.LoanApplication
Switched from age to dob on the Given part
Test really basic validation, common sense stuff
We don't want bankrupt people since 1990, or if their amount was over a certain amount

An enumeration is a mapping from fields to a list of values.This will mean the rule editor will show a drop down for fields, instead of a text box.The format of this is: 'FactType.fieldName': ['Value1', 'Value2'] You can add more mappings by adding in more lines. For example:
'Person.sex' : ['M', 'F'] 'Person.rating' : ['High', 'Low']
You can also ad display aliases (so the value used in the rule is separate to the one displayed: 'Person.sex' : ['M=Male', 'F=Female'] in the above case, the 'M=Male' means that 'Male' will be displayed as an item in a drop down box, but the value 'M' will be used in the rule.
Changed to any of the following

<rule> <name>No bad credit checks</name> <modelVersion>1.0</modelVersion> <attributes> <attribute> <attributeName>salience</attributeName> <value>10</value> </attribute> </attributes> <metadataList/> <lhs> <fact> <factType>LoanApplication</factType> <boundName>app</boundName> <isNegated>false</isNegated> </fact> <fact> <constraintList> <constraints> <compositeConstraint> <compositeJunctionType>||</compositeJunctionType> <constraints> <fieldConstraint> <value>F</value> <operator>==</operator> <constraintValueType>4</constraintValueType> <expression> <parts/> </expression> <fieldName>value</fieldName> <fieldType>String</fieldType> </fieldConstraint> <fieldConstraint> <value>D</value> <operator>==</operator> <constraintValueType>4</constraintValueType> <expression> <parts/> </expression> <fieldName>value</fieldName> <fieldType>String</fieldType> </fieldConstraint> <fieldConstraint> <value>C</value> <operator>==</operator> <constraintValueType>4</constraintValueType> <expression> <parts/> </expression> <fieldName>value</fieldName> <fieldType>String</fieldType> </fieldConstraint> </constraints> </compositeConstraint> </constraints> </constraintList> <factType>CreditRating</factType> <isNegated>false</isNegated> </fact> </lhs> <rhs> <setField> <fieldValues> <fieldValue> <field>approved</field> <value>false</value> <nature>1</nature> <type>Boolean</type> </fieldValue> <fieldValue> <field>explanation</field> <value>Not Acceptable Credit Rating</value> <nature>1</nature> <type>String</type> </fieldValue> </fieldValues> <variable>app</variable> </setField> <retract> <variableName>app</variableName> </retract> </rhs> <isNegated>false</isNegated> </rule>

[then]Approve the loan = applicant.setApproved(true)
[when]When the applicant dates is after {dos:DATE:default} = applicant:Applicant(applicationDate>"{dos}")
[when]When the applicant approval is {bool:BOOLEAN:checked} = applicant:Applicant(approved=={bool})
[when]When the ages is less than {num:1?[0-9]?[0-9]} = applicant:Applicant(age<{num})

declare Applicant age: Integer name: String creditRating: String end
declare IncomeSource amount: Integer type: String end
declare Bankruptcy amountOwed: Integer yearOfOccurrence: Integer end

An enumeration is a mapping from fields to a list of values.This will mean the rule editor will show a drop down for fields, instead of a text box.The format of this is: 'FactType.fieldName': ['Value1', 'Value2'] You can add more mappings by adding in more lines. For example:
'Person.sex' : ['M', 'F'] 'Person.rating' : ['High', 'Low']
You can also ad display aliases (so the value used in the rule is separate to the one displayed: 'Person.sex' : ['M=Male', 'F=Female'] in the above case, the 'M=Male' means that 'Male' will be displayed as an item in a drop down box, but the value 'M' will be used in the rule.

Archived Item on Wed Oct 01 12:54:56 GMT+1000 2008

An enumeration is a mapping from fields to a list of values.This will mean the rule editor will show a drop down for fields, instead of a text box.The format of this is: 'FactType.fieldName': ['Value1', 'Value2'] You can add more mappings by adding in more lines. For example:
'Person.sex' : ['M', 'F'] 'Person.rating' : ['High', 'Low']
You can also ad display aliases (so the value used in the rule is separate to the one displayed: 'Person.sex' : ['M=Male', 'F=Female'] in the above case, the 'M=Male' means that 'Male' will be displayed as an item in a drop down box, but the value 'M' will be used in the rule.
